>From: Derek James <djames@...>

> > Well that's not entirely true. If the useless appendages hinder the
> > organism or require a significant resources to grow and/or maintain then
> > individuals with these characteristics will be selected against over
> > time. But if the appendages aren't too expensive and aren't getting in
> > the way then they can indeed stick around. One that comes to mind is the
> > human appendix, and I've never found my little toe to be all that
> > useful. Well Ok you did say 'generally' - these 'extras' are mostly
> > special cases. I agree with the general priniciple that organisms don't
> > carry around loads of  appendages in the hope that one might become
> > useful, like some biological equivalent of a swiss army knife :)
>
>Well, I said "generally", but I also said "lots".  Of course there are
>instances of vestigial organs, but they are often small, withered, and
>negligible.  They are not doing enough harm to the organism to be
>strongly selected against, and the likelihood they they will become
>adaptive again at some later stage of evolution is remote.

However, an appendix isn't a neuron.  The likelihood of a neuron being able 
to be coopted into useful service is much higher than the chances of finding 
a use for the appendix.  So the analogy doesn't quite hold.
